                                                       10.12 References 301
Glossary

Accountability

When an organization takes responsibility for its actions and the consequences of those actions.

Aggravating factors

Factors that make a crime more serious and warrant a harsher punishment.

Appellant (petitioner)

The party who lost in the lower court and is appealing the decision to a higher court.

Appellate courts

Courts that review decisions made by trial courts.

Appellee (respondent)

The party who won in the lower court and is defending the decision on appeal.

Bench trial

A trial where a judge, rather than a jury, decides the case based on the evidence presented.

Case law

Laws established by rulings of appellate courts, also known as precedent.

Civil wrong

A violation of a legal duty that harms a person or entity, typically resulting in a lawsuit for damages.

Community corrections

A system that uses community-based programs and placements as alternatives to incarceration for all or
part of a sentence.

Community-oriented policing

A policing philosophy that emphasizes collaboration between police and community members to prevent
crime and improve public safety.

Consensus view

An idea that all groups come together, regardless of social class, race, age, gender, and more, to determine
what should be illegal.

Control theories

Theories that explain why more people do not engage in illegal behavior. These theories often assume
people are naturally selfish and, if left alone, would commit crimes.

Correctional facility

Secure buildings that house individuals accused of or convicted of crimes.

                                                                                                                                        303
Corrections officer

A sworn officer responsible for maintaining safety and security, as well as potentially offering guidance
and support, within a correctional facility.

Cost-benefit evaluations

An analysis that seeks to determine if the costs of a policy are justified by the benefits accrued.

Court of last resort

The highest court in a court system, such as the U.S. Supreme Court or a state supreme court.

Court-appointed attorney

A lawyer assigned by the court to represent a defendant who cannot afford their own attorney.

Courtroom workgroup

The collaborative relationship between judges, prosecutors, and defense attorneys who work together to
move cases through the court system.

Courts of general jurisdiction

Courts that can hear a wide variety of cases, including both felonies and misdemeanors.

Courts of limited jurisdiction

Courts that can only hear specific types of cases, typically minor offenses or civil matters.

Crime control model

A model that focuses on having an efficient system, with the most important function being to suppress
and control crime to ensure that society is safe and there is public order.

Crime prevention

Any action designed to reduce the actual level of crime and/or the perceived fear of crime.

Crimes against the person

Crimes that are often considered the most serious and may include homicide, rape, assault, kidnapping,
and intimate partner violence

Criminal justice system

The criminal justice system is a major social institution that is tasked with controlling crime in various
ways. It includes police, courts, and the correction system.

Criminal wrong

An act or omission that violates criminal law and is punishable by the state.

Criminalized act

When a deviant act becomes criminal, and a law is written with defined sanctions that can be enforced
by the criminal justice system.

304
Criminogenic needs

Factors that contribute to an individual's risk of committing crimes. Addressing these needs can help
reduce recidivism.

Dark figure

A phrase used to recognize that a large portion of crime each year is unreported.

Defense lawyers

Lawyers who represent defendants in criminal cases. They are responsible for investigating the case,
advising the defendant, and presenting a defense in court.

Deterrence

The goal of discouraging criminal behavior through punishment or the threat of punishment.

Deviance

Behavior that departs from or violates the established social norm.

Discretionary waiver

Also known as a regular waiver, allows a judge to transfer a juvenile from juvenile court to adult criminal
court. The burden of proof rests with the state to prove the juvenile is not amenable to treatment in juve-
nile court.

Disposition

The sentence or punishment imposed by the court on a juvenile offender.

Disproportionate minority contact (DMC)

The phenomenon where juveniles of color are more likely to be involved in the juvenile justice system
than white juveniles, even when accounting for differences in crime rates.

Diversion

The process of directing someone away from the formal criminal justice system, often into social services
or treatment programs.

Dual court system

The system in the United States where there are separate state and federal court systems. State courts
handle state law violations, while federal courts handle federal law violations.

Evidence-based practices

Using research and data to guide decisions about criminal justice policies and programs, with the goal of
improving outcomes for individuals.

Ex parte Crouse

An 1838 court case that established the concept of parens patriae, the idea that the state has the authority
to act in the best interests of a child.

                                                                                                                                        305
Ex post facto laws

Laws that retroactively apply to actions committed before the law was enacted. These are generally pro-
hibited by the Constitution.

Facility design-linear

A jail design focused on space efficiency, with long hallways lined by cells holding a large number of peo-
ple.

Facility design-podular

A jail design that emphasizes a more communal feel, with multiple cells facing a central living area allow-
ing for easier supervision.

Feminist criminology

A critical framework that examines the relationship between gender, crime, and justice.

Folk devils

People who are blamed for being allegedly responsible for the threat to society.

Folkways

Behaviors that are learned and shared by a social group. Often referred to as customs.

Fourth Amendment

The amendment to the United States Constitution that prohibits unreasonable searches and seizures and
requires warrants to be issued upon probable cause.

Framing

When the media focuses on the broad categories, segments, or angles through which a story can be told,
such as factual and interpretive claims that allow people to organize events and experiences into groups.

Hedonism

The philosophical idea that pleasure is the primary good and that people naturally seek to maximize plea-
sure and avoid pain.

Impact (outcome) evaluations

An investigation of what has changed after the introduction of a crime policy.

Incapacitation

Removing an individual from society for a set period to prevent them from committing crimes.

Inchoate crimes

Attempted crimes where a person takes a substantial step towards committing a crime, but the crime
itself is not completed.

Jail

A facility that holds people accused of crimes awaiting trial or those convicted of minor offenses.

306
Jim Crow laws

Laws in the United States, enacted between 1877 and the 1960s, that enforced racial segregation in the
South.

Judicial waiver

A process where a juvenile court judge can transfer a case to adult criminal court.

Jurisdiction

The authority of a court to hear and decide a case.

Jury trial

A trial where a jury decides the facts of the case based on the evidence presented.

Juvenile delinquency

Antisocial or criminal behavior by a minor.

Labeling theories

Theories that focus on the social construction of crime and why not everyone who commits a crime is
labeled as a criminal. These theories point out that definitions of crime can vary over time and place.

Law

A system of rules enforced through social institutions to govern behavior.

Learning theories

Theories that focus on how people learn criminal behavior through processes of reinforcement and imi-
tation.

Legislative waiver

A law that automatically excludes certain offenses from juvenile court jurisdiction.

Mandatory waiver

A process where a juvenile offender meeting certain criteria (like age and offense type) must be trans-
ferred to adult criminal court.

Mass incarceration

The phenomenon of the United States having the highest incarceration rate in the world.

Mental health

A person's emotional, psychological, and social well-being. Mental health includes our emotional, psy-
chological, and social well-being. It affects how we think, feel, and act. It also helps determine how we
handle stress, relate to others, and make choices.

Miranda rights

Constitutional rights in the United States that protect individuals during police questioning. These rights
include the right to remain silent and the right to an attorney.

                                                                                                                                        307
Misdemeanor

These are the least dangerous types of crimes which can include, depending on the location, public intox-
ication, prostitution, and graffiti, among others.

Mitigating factors

Circumstances that lessen the seriousness of a crime and may lead to a lighter sentence.

Moral panic

When public fears and state interventions greatly exceed the objective threat posed to society by a partic-
ular individual or group

Moral wrong

An act or omission that is considered wrong according to personal beliefs or ethical codes, but not nec-
essarily illegal.

Narratives

Pictures and popular stories that the public accepts and perceives as correct.

Official statistics

Reported statistics, self-report statistics, and victimization statistics that are reported to various official
government criminal justice agencies, such as the police and courts.

Original jurisdiction

The authority of a court to hear a case for the first time, as opposed to reviewing a decision made by a
lower court.

Overcrowding

When the number of incarcerated individuals exceeds the capacity of correctional facilities.

Parens patriae

A legal concept that gives the state the authority to act in the best interests of a child, including protecting
them from neglect or abuse.

Parole

The release of a prisoner under supervision after serving a portion of their sentence.

Policy development

A process that typically begins with identifying the issue to be addressed by the proposed policy, and ends
with evaluation to see whether the policy has resolved the issues.

Positivism

An approach to criminology that emphasizes the use of scientific methods to study crime and develop
solutions.

Post-prison supervision

A period of supervision following release from prison, with conditions similar to parole.

308
Presumptive waiver

A process that shifts the burden of proof to the juvenile to demonstrate why they should remain in juve-
nile court.

Principle of orality

The rule that only evidence presented in court can be considered by the judge or jury in making a deci-
sion.

Prison

A facility that houses people convicted of serious crimes and sentenced to long terms of incarceration.

Probation

A sentence that allows a convicted person to remain in the community under the supervision of a proba-
tion officer, instead of going to jail or prison.

Process evaluation

Assessments that consider the implementation of a policy or program and involve determining the pro-
cedure used to implement the policy.

Prosecutor

A government attorney who represents the state in criminal cases and is responsible for bringing charges
against defendants and arguing for their conviction.

Prosecutorial waiver

A system where prosecutors have the discretion to decide whether to file charges against a juvenile in
juvenile or adult court.

Punishment

A penalty imposed on someone who has committed a crime.

Qualitative research

Involves exploring and understanding human experiences and behaviors by delving into in-depth narra-
tives, like personal stories and interviews.

Quantitative research

Uses numerical data and statistical analysis to identify patterns and draw conclusions, such as counting
and measuring to uncover trends.

Rehabilitation

The process of helping someone who has committed a crime change their behavior and become a pro-
ductive member of society.

Respondents

Survey participants.

                                                                                                                                        309
Restorative justice

A community-based approach to justice that focuses on repairing harm, building relationships, and hold-
ing offenders accountable.

Retribution

Punishment focused on revenge or payback for a crime.

Rule of law

The principle that everyone, including those in power, is subject to the same laws.

School-to-prison pipeline

The phenomenon where disciplinary actions in school can lead students into the juvenile justice system.

Search and seizure

The government's authority to search for and take away evidence of crimes. The Fourth Amendment lim-
its this power to protect people from unreasonable searches and seizures.

Self-report statistics

Data that are reported by individuals.

Situational crime prevention

Strategies that aim to reduce crime by making opportunities for crime less attractive or increasing the
perceived risk of getting caught.

Social disorganization theory

A theory that suggests crime is more likely to occur in areas with weak social institutions (such as family,
school, religion, or government) that cannot effectively control behavior.

Specialty courts

Courts designed to handle specific types of cases, such as drug courts or mental health courts.

Status offenses

Offenses that are only illegal because of the age of the offender, such as underage drinking or truancy.

Strain theories

Theories that focus on how social and economic strain can push people into crime. These theories
assume that human beings are naturally good but that bad things happen, which push people into crimi-
nal activity.

Superpredator

A media-created stereotype of a violent and uncontrollable juvenile offender, which influenced harsher
juvenile justice policies.

Supervision style-direct

A supervision approach where officers are stationed directly within the living unit with the incarcerated
individuals.

310
Supervision style-indirect

A supervision approach where officers monitor the unit from a separate control room and have less
direct contact with those incarcerated.

Survey research

A quantitative and qualitative research method that asks participants (respondents) to report directly on
their own thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.

Theory

An explanation that attempts to make sense of our observations about the world.

U.S. Court of Appeals

Intermediate appellate courts that review decisions of U.S. District Courts within their circuit.

U.S. District Courts

The trial courts in the federal court system.

U.S. Supreme Court

The highest court in the United States, with the authority to review decisions of all lower federal courts
and state courts.

Use of force

The level of physical force used by law enforcement officers to control a situation or apprehend a suspect.
This can range from verbal commands to deadly force.

Victim

One who has suffered direct or threatened physical, financial, or emotional harm as a result of the com-
mission of a crime.

Victim-impact statements

Accounts by the victim, the victim's family, or others affected by the offense that express the effects of the
offense.

Victimization studies

Surveys that ask people if they have been a victim of a crime in a given year.

Writ of certiorari (rule of four)

A petition filed with the Supreme Court requesting that it review a lower court decision. The Supreme
Court only grants certiorari in about 10% of the cases it is asked to review.

Writs of habeas corpus

A legal document that challenges the legality of a person's imprisonment.

                                                                                                                                        311

         into in-depth narratives, like personal stories and interviews.

         conclusions, such as counting and measuring to uncover trends.

     3. Meta-analysis: a research method that involves combining data from multiple studies to draw
         conclusions about a particular research question or topic.

     4. Cross-sectional Research: subjects are randomly assigned into an intervention group and a con-
         trol group.

     5. Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT): subjects are randomly assigned into an intervention group
         and a control group.

Chapter 4: Criminal Law

1. Which of the following research terms are correctly matched with their definition?

     1. Criminal wrong: behaviors that harm society as a whole rather than one individual or entity
         specifically.

     2. Civil wrong: Law that attempts to perfect personal character. There are no codes or statutes gov-
         erning violations of moral laws in the United States.

     3. Moral wrong: A private wrong, and the injured party's remedy is to sue the party who caused the
         wrong/injury for general damages (money).

2. Which of the following is correct about substantive and procedural law?

     1. Violating substantive laws is a federal crime, and violating procedural laws is a misdemeanor.
     2. Substantive law defines what conduct is criminal, and procedural law gives us the mechanisms to

         enforce substantive law.
     3. Substantive laws are larger, more substantial laws, and procedural laws are smaller.
     4. Substantive and procedural law are different names for the same thing.
3. The U.S. Constitution limits certain types of legislation and substantive law. It provides procedural
    constraints on the government regarding how to prosecute individuals for crimes.

     1. True
     2. False
4. What is the Rule of Law?

     1. A law that is retroactively applied.
     2. The laws that originate from appellate court opinions written by judges.
     3. The belief that everyone is equal before the law and that the same set of laws applies to everyone.
     4. The absence of judicial review.

                                                                                                                                        315
5. Which source of law is correctly matched with its definition? Select all that apply.

     1. Common law: written statements enacted into law by an affirmative vote of both chambers of
         the legislature and accepted (or not vetoed) by the governor of the state or the President of the
         United States.

     2. Case law: legal rules announced in opinions written by appellate judges when deciding appellate
         cases before them.

     3. Statutes: common law rules brought over from England to the United States when it became a
         nation.

Chapter 5: Criminological Theory

1. Which explanation of criminal behavior is matched to the right definition? Select all that apply.

     1. Classical Theory: The idea that criminal behavior has other causes beyond choice based on mea-
         surement, objectivity, and causality.

     2. Positivist Criminology: The idea that people are responsible for their actions because the action
         is a choice.

     3. Biological and Psychological Theories: The idea that there are inherent differences between
         criminals and noncriminals, and these differences can be uncovered through scientific study.

2. Which of the following theories best describes the crime control policy (method) used in this sce-
    nario: As a local business owner, you are having trouble with customers' cars being broken into in
    the parking lot of your business after dark. You believe this crime is occurring because the parking
    lot is dark and there are no cameras. You theorize that perpetrators are breaking into cars because
    they believe they will not get caught. You install bright lights, cameras, and signs letting potential
    offenders know that the lot is monitored 24-7.

     1. Rational Choice Theory
     2. Retribution
     3. Incapacitation
3. What is the difference between specific deterrence and general deterrence?

     1. They are the same.
     2. Specific deterrence showcases the consequences faced by others who engage in similar behavior,

         and general deterrence tries to dissuade an individual offender from committing future crimes
         by imposing penalties or consequences.
     3. General deterrence showcases the consequences faced by others who engage in similar behavior,
         and specific deterrence tries to dissuade an individual offender from committing future crimes
         by imposing penalties or consequences.
     4. Specific deterrence has much more strict consequences than general deterrence.
4. What did the Chicago School theory of crime say about the "transition zone"? Select all that apply.

     3. Less crime happened in the transition zone because it was developing so quickly.

     4. Living in the transition zone made it tough for people to feel connected to each other, and with-
         out strong connections, especially for young people, it was easier for crime to happen.

5. Which criminological ideology is correctly matched to its definition?

     1. Neoclassical theory: Three things must converge in time and space for a crime to be committed.
         They include a motivated offender, a suitable target, and the absence of a capable guardian.

     2. Rational Choice Theory: Offenders rationally calculate costs and benefits before committing
         crime, and it expects some people will always commit a crime when given the opportunity.

     3. Routine Activity Theory: Individuals experience punishment differently and recognizes that a
         person's environment, psychology, and other factors can influence their likelihood of committing
         crimes.

     1. The prosecutor: The lawyer who represents the person accused of a crime. They help the person
         after charges are filed and keep helping them until the end of the trial, including during the sen-
         tencing if the person is found guilty.

     2. The defense attorney: Brings charges against someone and represents the state during the trial.

Chapter 8: Corrections

1. Which ideology of punishment is correctly matched to its definition? Select all that apply.

     1. Retribution: punishment that is imposed on a person as revenge or vengeance for a criminal act
         that they committed in the past.

     2. Deterrence: punishment that is designed to discourage individuals from offending by imposing
         punishment sanctions or threatening such sanctions.

     3. Incapacitation: the removal of an individual from society for a set amount of time so they cannot
         commit crimes.

     4. Rehabilitation: the ideology that individuals who have committed crimes can't change their
         behavior through interventions, treatment, therapy, education, and training in order to help
         them reenter society.

2. Which of the following are true about the emergence of jails in the United States? Select all that
    apply.

     1. The concept of a jail was brought from Western Europe when the U.S. criminal justice systems
         were first formed.

     3. U.S. jails didn't emerge until 1898 in Arizona.
     4. Historically, many jails were nothing more than parts of a sheriff's office, literally cells in the

         back room - but today, large structures constitute jails in the United States.

    space, allowing an officer to be in the middle of the unit and see the majority of the occupants of the
    cells around them.

     1. True
     2. False

     1. Prisons are only managed by the federal government.
     2. Jails house people who have been accused of crimes, but not convicted.
     3. A jail is a place in which individuals accused or convicted of crimes are held, and a prison is a

         place in which individuals convicted of felony crimes are held.
     4. Jails are intended to house people convicted of felonies for the long term.

     1. Intake center: Classifies felony-convicted individuals coming from courts in the jurisdiction.
     2. Minimum prisons: Have dorm-style housing and are typically for only nonviolent individuals

         with shorter sentences.
     3. Medium prisons: Have cells rather than dorms, and freedom of movement within the institution

         is reduced and seen as a privilege.

                                                                                                                                        319
     4. Maximum prisons: include different missions such as supermax and individuals stay in their
         (usually single-occupancy) cells for the entire day, every day.

     5. Administrative prisons: Has mostly single-occupancy cells, and many but not all individuals
         housed here will spend most of their day in a cell. Freedom of movement is reduced and seen as a
         privilege.

Chapter 9: Community Corrections

1. Which type of community corrections is correctly matched to its definition? Select all that apply.

     1. Diversion: a process where an individual, at some stage, is routed away from continuing on in
         the formal justice process.

     2. Probation: where an individual is remanded to stay home for confinement as a punishment, in
         lieu of jail or prison.

     3. Boot camps: Programs that are designed around a militaristic ideal and operated on the assump-
         tion that a regimen of strict physical exercise would teach structure and discipline to youths.

     4. House arrest: a form of a suspended sentence where the jail or prison sentence of the convicted
         individual is suspended for the privilege of serving conditions of supervision in the community.

     5. Halfway houses: a stopping point for individuals coming out of prisons to assist with reentry
         into the community. They have also recently been used as more secure measures of monitoring
         individuals in place of going to prison. (correct)

     6. Parole: an individual's release (under conditions) after serving a portion of their sentence. It is
         also accompanied by the threat of re-incarceration if warranted.

     2. False

Answer Key

Chapter 1: Crime, Criminal Justice, and Criminology

1. Which of the following are the three component parts of the criminal justice system?
     1. Police, Law Enforcement, Sheriff's Office
     2. Judges, Court Clerks, Public Defenders
     3. Jails, Prisons, Parole
     4. Courts, Police, Corrections (correct)
     5. Answer feedback: The criminal justice system is part of every level of government. Agencies

                                                                                                                                        321
         associated with these levels work together or work separately. This book explores each of the
         three main components of the criminal justice system.
2. Select all the accurate definitions from the list below.

     1. Interactionist View: Implies agreement among citizens on what should and should not be illegal.
     2. Consensus View: Acts should be prohibited and punished under criminal law when it is deemed

         socially harmful or dangerous to society.
     3. Conflict View: This view recognizes that the creation of laws is unequal and may not have agree-

         ment as society is a collection of diverse groups. (correct)
     4. Answer feedback: An Interactionist View wants a crime to be punished when it is socially harm-

         ful or dangerous. Consensus View invites all social groups to come together to determine what
         should be illegal. Conflict View recognizes that consensus may not be impossible.
3. Select all the accurate definitions from the list below.

     1. Deviance is behavior that departs from or violates the established social norm. (correct)
     2. Folkways are behaviors that are learned and shared by a social group. (correct)
     3. Mores are norms of morality, or right and wrong. (correct)
     4. Taboo is a very positive norm that pleases everyone.
     5. Answer feedback: In fact, taboorefers to a very negative norm that should not be violated because

         people will be upset.
4. Which of the following statements about victims are true? Select all that apply.

     1. A victim of crime did not exist until well into the 17th century. (correct)
     2. Over the years, different typologies of victims have been created to demonstrate the unique role

         or position of victims in relation to crime. (correct)
     3. The U.S. criminal justice system first introduced services for victims of federal criminal

         offenses during the 1980s. (correct)
     4. Answer feedback: A victimas a person who has been directly harmed by a crime that was com-

         mitted by another person. In the 1990s, Congress created the Victim's Rights and Restitution Act
         H.R.5368, putting services for victims of federal criminal offenses into law.
5. A misdemeanor is a serious offense that is punishable by a sentence of more than one year in prison
    and sometimes by death.

     1. True
     2. False (correct)
     3. Answer feedback: In fact, it is a felony that is a serious offense. It is punishable by a sentence of

         more than one year in prison and sometimes by death.

Chapter 2: Criminal Justice Policy

1. Which of the following statements about control and prevention are accurate? Select all that apply.

     1. Control refers to the actions and measures taken by authorities to manage and reduce crime after
         it has happened. (correct)

     2. Police investigations, arrests, trials, and punishments are part of control. (correct)
     3. Prevention is about stopping crime from happening in the first place. (correct)

322
     4. Examples of prevention include community policing, neighborhood watch programs, educa-
         tional campaigns, and creating safe spaces for people. (correct)

     5. Answer feedback: "Control" refers to actions taken to manage crime after it occurs, like police
         investigations and punishments. "Prevention" focuses on stopping crime before it happens,
         through efforts like community policing and educational campaigns.

2. Moral panic is when public fears and state interventions greatly exceed the objective threat that folk
    devils pose to society.

     1. True (correct)
     2. False
     3. Answer feedback: In moral panic, the people and the state get very worried, even if the actual

         danger is exaggerated.Folk devils become the focus of people's fear even if the fears aren't justi-
         fied. This is how juvenile offenders became "super-predators" in the 1990s.
3. Which stage of policy developmenthappens last?

     1. Identifying
     2. Placement
     3. Formulation
     4. Implementation
     5. Evaluation (correct)
     6. Answer feedback: The five stages of policy development include Identifying the Issue, Placement

         on the Agenda, Formulation, Implementation, and Evaluation. Evaluation happens last. This is
         when researchers gather data and analyze results.
4. When the media focuses on the broad categories, segments, or angles through which a story can be
    told, such as factual and interpretive claims that allow people to organize events and experiences
    into groups, it is called framing.

     1. True (correct)
     2. False
     3. Answer feedback: Framing is a way of setting an agenda in a packaged manner, and narratives

         are all about the story being told.
5. Which of the following are reasons criminal justice policies are re-evaluated or changed after they're

    created? Select all that apply.

     1. Public outcry (correct)
     2. Media attention (correct)
     3. Statistical data showing results that were less than desirable in regards to the intent of the origi-

         nal policy (correct)
     4. Answer feedback: Some of these re-evaluations have been a result of public outcry and media

         attention, and others have been related to statistical data showing results that were less than
         desirable in regard to the intent of the original policy.

Chapter 3: Defining and Measuring Crime and Criminal Justice

1. Which of the following research terms are correctly matched with their definition?

                                                                                                                                        323
     1. Qualitative Research: exploring and understanding human experiences and behaviors by delving
         into in-depth narratives, like personal stories and interviews. (correct)

     2. Quantitative Research: Uses numerical data and statistical analysis to identify patterns and draw
         conclusions, such as counting and measuring to uncover trends. (correct)

     3. Meta-analysis: a research method that involves combining data from multiple studies to draw
         conclusions about a particular research question or topic. (correct)

     4. Cross-sectional Research: subjects are randomly assigned into an intervention group and a con-
         trol group.

     5. Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT): subjects are randomly assigned into an intervention group
         and a control group.

     6. Answer feedback: It is important to study research methods to determine which method would
         work best in a particular scenario. The method you select will depend on the information you
         need, and there are advantages and disadvantages to each method.

2. What are some of the limitations of self-report statistics of crimes? Select all that apply.

     1. Respondents may exaggerate their criminal behavior. (correct)
     2. Poor sampling methods can easily skew the results. (correct)
     3. Respondents may underreport their criminal behavior. (correct)
     4. There are no limitations. Self-report is the gold standard.
     5. Answer feedback: Self-report data has limitations because people report their own crimes to a

         survey. Respondents may exaggerate or underreport their criminal behavior, and if poor statisti-
         cal sampling methods are used, the survey responses may be skewed.
3. The misuse of statistics can promote crime myths and generate fear of crime.

     1. True (correct)
     2. False
     3. Answer feedback: Data can be used inappropriately. Examples include limiting public access to

         information, misleading the public with false information, or using deceptive formats to present
         information. This can promote crime myths and generate fear of crime.
4. What do victimization studies and self-report statistics have in common?

     1. They both guarantee accurate results.
     2. Their data is based on responses that are self-reported by survey respondents. (correct)
     3. Neither are used in crime reporting in the United States.
     4. Answer feedback: Both are based on self-reported data. Victimization studies ask people if they

         experienced a crime and if they reported it or not. Self-report statistics are from survey reports
         about the number of times a person committed a particular crime.
5. Victimization studies can improve crime statistics.

     1. True (correct)
     2. False
     3. Answer feedback: Victimization studies can fill in missing crimes on police reports. The National

         Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS) closes crime data gaps with data on the frequency, charac-
         teristics, and consequences of criminal victimization.

324
Chapter 4: Criminal Law

1. Which of the following research terms are correctly matched with their definition?

     1. Criminal wrong: behaviors that harm society as a whole rather than one individual or entity
         specifically. (correct)

     2. Civil wrong: Law that attempts to perfect personal character. There are no codes or statutes gov-
         erning violations of moral laws in the United States.

     3. Moral wrong: A private wrong, and the injured party's remedy is to sue the party who caused the
         wrong/injury for general damages (money).

     4. Answer feedback: It is important to understand the different types of wrongs. Criminal wrongs
         are only one type of wrong. People can also violate civil law or commit a moral wrong and not be
         guilty of any crime whatsoever.

2. Which of the following is correct about substantive and procedural law?

     1. Violating substantive laws is a federal crime, and violating procedural laws is a misdemeanor.
     2. Substantive law defines what conduct is criminal, and procedural law gives us the mechanisms to

         enforce substantive law. (correct)
     3. Substantive laws are larger, more substantial laws, and procedural laws are smaller.
     4. Substantive and procedural law are different names for the same thing.
     5. Answer feedback: Law can be either substantive or procedural. Criminal and civil laws can be

         either. Substantive law defines criminal conduct. Procedural law names mechanisms to enforce
         substantive law, like the rights of parties and rules for investigations and trials.
3. The U.S. Constitution limits certain types of legislation and substantive law. It provides procedural
    constraints on the government regarding how to prosecute individuals for crimes.

     1. True (correct)
     2. False
     3. Answer feedback: The U.S. Constitution plays a major role. In addition to setting types of laws

         and procedural constraints, it requires the separation of powers between the three branches of
         government. It also limits Congress's authority to pass laws outside its powers.
4. What is the Rule of Law?

     1. A law that is retroactively applied.
     2. The laws that originate from appellate court opinions written by judges.
     3. The belief that everyone is equal before the law and that the same set of laws applies to everyone.

         (correct)
     4. The absence of judicial review.
     5. Answer feedback: The Rule of Law is the belief that everyone is equal before the law and that the

         same set of laws applies to everyone. This principle is crucial because it protects individuals from
         arbitrary decisions and ensures that justice is impartial.
5. Which source of law is correctly matched with its definition? Select all that apply.

     1. Common law: written statements enacted into law by an affirmative vote of both chambers of
         the legislature and accepted (or not vetoed) by the governor of the state or the President of the
         United States.

                                                                                                                                        325
     2. Case law: legal rules announced in opinions written by appellate judges when deciding appellate
         cases before them. (correct)

     3. Statutes: common law rules brought over from England to the United States when it became a
         nation.

     4. Answer feedback: Statutes are written statements enacted into law by an affirmative vote of the
         legislature and accepted by a state governor or the President of the United States. Common law
         was brought over from England to the United States when it became a nation.

Chapter 5: Criminological Theory

1. Which explanation of criminal behavior is matched to the right definition? Select all that apply.

     1. Classical Theory: The idea that criminal behavior has other causes beyond choice based on mea-
         surement, objectivity, and causality.

     2. Positivist Criminology: The idea that people are responsible for their actions because the action
         is a choice.

     3. Biological and Psychological Theories: The idea that there are inherent differences between
         criminals and noncriminals, and these differences can be uncovered through scientific study.
         (correct)

     4. Answer feedback: The criminal justice system is based on the assumption that crime is a choice
         and that offenders are totally responsible for their actions. Different ideas have developed,
         including that certain traits predispose someone to criminal behavior.

2. Which of the following theories best describes the crime control policy (method) used in this sce-
    nario: As a local business owner, you are having trouble with customers' cars being broken into in
    the parking lot of your business after dark. You believe this crime is occurring because the parking
    lot is dark and there are no cameras. You theorize that perpetrators are breaking into cars because
    they believe they will not get caught. You install bright lights, cameras, and signs letting potential
    offenders know that the lot is monitored 24-7.

     1. Rational Choice Theory (correct)
     2. Retribution
     3. Incapacitation
     4. Answer feedback: Rational Choice Theoryclaims that people calculate costs and benefits before

         committing a crime and that people want to maximize pleasure and minimize pain. When
         offenders believe they will get caught, the pain of committing the crime stops them.
3. What is the difference between specific deterrence and general deterrence?

     1. They are the same.
     2. Specific deterrence showcases the consequences faced by others who engage in similar behavior,

         and general deterrence tries to dissuade an individual offender from committing future crimes
         by imposing penalties or consequences.
     3. General deterrence showcases the consequences faced by others who engage in similar behavior,
         and specific deterrence tries to dissuade an individual offender from committing future crimes
         by imposing penalties or consequences. (correct)

326
     4. Specific deterrence has much more strict consequences than general deterrence.
     5. Answer feedback: General deterrence uses punishment to deter crime among people in the gen-

         eral population. It uses punishment as an example for those people who are not being punished.
         Specific deterrence uses punishment to reduce the crime of particular persons.
4. What did the Chicago School theory of crime say about the "transition zone"?

     1. Most crime happened in an area called the transition zone. (correct)
     2. People in the transition zone had more problems like sickness and poor mental health. (correct)
     3. Less crime happened in the transition zone because it was developing so quickly.
     4. Living in the transition zone made it tough for people to feel connected to each other, and with-

         out strong connections, especially for young people, it was easier for crime to happen. (correct)
     5. Answer feedback: Clifford Shaw and Henry McKay mapped the addresses of young males sent to

         juvenile court. They found that most crimes happened in the transition zone. They were among
         the first to say that where you live can affect whether you turn to crime.
5. Which criminological ideology is correctly matched to its definition?

     1. Neoclassical theory: Three things must converge in time and space for a crime to be committed.
         They include a motivated offender, a suitable target, and the absence of a capable guardian.

     2. Rational Choice Theory: Offenders rationally calculate costs and benefits before committing
         crime, and it expects some people will always commit a crime when given the opportunity. (cor-
         rect)

     3. Routine Activity Theory: Individuals experience punishment differently and recognizes that a
         person's environment, psychology, and other factors can influence their likelihood of committing
         crimes.

     4. Answer feedback: Rational Choice Theory and Routine Activity Theory are neoclassical. Many
         crime-prevention efforts have adopted classical and neoclassical principles, focusing on "what
         works" to prevent crime rather than why individuals engage in criminal behavior.

Chapter 6: Policing

1. Policing in the United States has stayed the same since its development in the 19th century.

     1. True
     2. False (correct)
     3. Answer feedback: Policing in the United States has evolved since its roots in the common law of

         England. It experienced the Political Era, the Reform Era, the Community Era, and today, the
         Homeland Security Era. Each era impacted its organization and its areas of focus.
2. Which level of policing is correctly matched to the type of law enforcement officers that work at that
    level? Select all that apply.

     1. Federal: Customs and Border Protection (correct)
     2. State: Highway Patrol (correct)
     3. County: Office of the Sheriff (correct)
     4. City: Transportation specialists
     5. Answer feedback: When they think of police, most individuals think of their local police depart-

                                                                                                                                        327
         ments, i.e., city or county agencies. In reality, there are various police entities with diverse
         responsibilities at various levels of the government.
3. Officer discretion plays a significant role in shaping the outcomes of law enforcement encounters
    and the administration of justice and can allow officers to make decisions based on their judgment
    and interpretation of laws and policies. Which of the following are potential risks of police discre-
    tion? Select all that apply.

     1. Police discretion introduces the potential for bias and inconsistency in decision-making. (cor-
         rect)

     2. Police discretion guarantees that officers will make problematic decisions.
     3. Police discretion may be influenced by personal biases, attitudes, and perceptions. (correct)
     4. Police discretion can negatively intersect with broader societal issues, such as race, socioeco-

         nomic status, and community-police relations. (correct)
     5. Answer feedback: Officers exercise discretion in their duties, including whether to make an

         arrest, issue a citation, or provide a warning, as well how to respond to conflicts and emergen-
         cies. Personal or institutional biases can - but don't always - impact discretion.
4. Which of the following are wellness issues, beyond line-of-duty deaths, that police officers are at risk
    of?

     1. None. Police are well-equipped to deal with personal physical and mental health issues.
     2. Stress-related mental health challenges (correct)
     3. Suicide (correct)
     4. Trauma (correct)
     5. Answer feedback: Officers are at risk of multiple physical and mental health issues. Addressing

         the mental health challenges faced by officers is essential in safeguarding their well-being and
         ensuring their ability to serve and protect their communities effectively.
5. Based on what you have read in this chapter, what do community-oriented policing, body cameras,
    and crisis intervention teams have in common?

     1. They are all costly programs that detract from the mission of police.
     2. They are initiatives that were brought forth by the political era of policing.
     3. They are all interventions that only take place at the federal level of policing.
     4. They are initiatives that attempt to improve the ways that police work with the community by

         training and increasing accountability. (correct)
     5. Answer feedback: Training and increasing accountability can improve the way police work in a

         community. Finding ways to foster a collaborative and proactive manner can further public
         safety.

Chapter 7: Courts

1. Trial courts deal with basic facts. They have jurisdiction over pretrial matters, trials, sentencing, pro-
    bation, and parole violations.

     1. True (correct)
     2. False

328
    3. Answer feedback: The trial court tries a case and decides the outcome. In contrast, the appellate
         court can overrule that outcome if a serious mistake is made by the trial court. The federal and
         state court systems have hierarchies that divide trial and appellate courts.

2. In the courts, jurisdiction refers to the legal power to hear and decide a case. Which of the following
    are factors that determine a court's jurisdiction? Select all that apply.

    1. Court function (correct)
    2. Subject matter (correct)
    3. Judge's interest
    4. Seriousness of case (correct)
    5. Court's authority (correct)
    6. Ability to find a willing jury
    7. Geographic location (correct)
    8. Answer feedback: Understanding jurisdiction helps clarify where legal actions can be pursued

         effectively. The factors that determine a court's jurisdiction are court function, subject matter,
         the seriousness of a case, the court's authority, and the geographic location.
3. Which members of the courtroom workgroup are correctly matched to a description of the tasks
    they do in court? Select all that apply.

    1. The prosecutor: The lawyer who represents the person accused of a crime. They help the person
         after charges are filed and keep helping them until the end of the trial, including during the sen-
         tencing if the person is found guilty.

    2. The defense attorney: Brings charges against someone and represents the state during the trial.
         Also negotiates with the defendant's lawyer before the trial and talks to the judge during the trial
         and at the sentencing.

    3. The judge: The person in charge of the trial. They have several people helping them, such as
         clerks and other court staff. The judge listens to both sides during the trial and makes sure that
         everything is done fairly. (correct)

    4. Answer feedback: Prosecutors bring charges, defense attorneys help the accused, and judges are
         in charge. They each make sure the trial is fair and follows the law. They all went to law school
         and passed a test to become lawyers and work together to resolve cases.

4. Each state in the U.S. has its own court system.

    1. True (correct)
    2. False
    3. Answer feedback: Each state in the United States has its own court system, separate from the fed-

         eral court system. Essentially, we have 51 legal systems. U.S. Territories and the military have
         their own court systems. This is often referred to as the dual court system.
5. Select all true statements about the appellate (appeals) process.

    1. When disputes are not satisfactorily resolved in the trial courts, each party can petition the
         appeals court to review the case. (correct)

    2. The main job of the appeals court that reviews the case is to check if any mistakes were made
         during the trial. (correct)

    3. Although the defendant is permitted to appeal after entering a guilty plea, the only basis for their
         appeal is to challenge the sentence given. (correct)

                                                                                                                                        329
     4. A lower court's judgment will not be reversed unless the appellant can show that a serious error
         was made by the lower court. (correct)

     5. Answer feedback: In routine appeals, appellate courts review the record for errors. The goal is to
         ensure a fair trial. By reviewing for errors and then writing opinions that become case law,
         appellate courts perform dual functions: error correction and lawmaking.

Chapter 8: Corrections

1. Which ideology of punishment is correctly matched to its definition? Select all that apply.

     1. Retribution: punishment that is imposed on a person as revenge or vengeance for a criminal act
         that they committed in the past. (correct)

     2. Deterrence: punishment that is designed to discourage individuals from offending by imposing
         punishment sanctions or threatening such sanctions. (correct)

     3. Incapacitation: the removal of an individual from society for a set amount of time so they cannot
         commit crimes (correct)

     4. Rehabilitation: the ideology that individuals who have committed crimes can't change their
         behavior through interventions, treatment, therapy, education, and training in order to help
         them reenter society.

     5. Answer feedback: Rehabilitation holds that people can change. Forward-looking ideologies are
         designed to reduce the level of recidivism through some type of change. How society views pun-
         ishment is impacted by the dominant culture, politics, and even religion.

2. Which of the following are true about the emergence of jails in the United States?

     1. The concept of a jail was brought from Western Europe when the U.S. criminal justice systems
         were first formed. (correct)

     2. The vast majority of jails hold less than 50 individuals. (correct)
     3. U.S. jails didn't emerge until 1898 in Arizona.
     4. Historically, many jails were nothing more than parts of a sheriff's office, literally cells in the

         back room - but today, large structures constitute jails in the United States. (correct)
     5. Answer feedback: A jail is a place in which individuals accused or convicted of crimes are held.

         The concept was brought from Europe when the U.S. criminal justice systems were first formed.
         U.S. Jails are diverse in size and have changed in size and structure over time.
3. Podular-design facilities are built for communal living. Multiple cells face toward a central living
    space, allowing an officer to be in the middle of the unit and see the majority of the occupants of the
    cells around them.

     1. True (correct)
     2. False
     3. Answer feedback: Jails vary greatly in design, function, and size. The two main types of facility

         design models are the older generation, or linear design, and the newer generation, or podular
         design.
4. What is the difference between jail and prison?

     1. Prisons are only managed by the federal government.

330
     2. Jails house people who have been accused of crimes, but not convicted.
     3. A jail is a place in which individuals accused or convicted of crimes are held, and a prison is a

         place in which individuals convicted of felony crimes are held. (correct)
     4. Jails are intended to house people convicted of felonies for the long term.
     5. Answer feedback: Jails are places in which individuals accused or convicted of crimes are held,

         and prisons are places in which individuals convicted of felony crimes are held.
5. Which type of prison facility is correctly matched to its definition?

     1. Intake center: Classifies felony-convicted individuals coming from courts in the jurisdiction.
         (correct)

     2. Minimum prisons: Have dorm-style housing and are typically for only nonviolent individuals
         with shorter sentences. (correct)

     3. Medium prisons: Have cells rather than dorms, and freedom of movement within the institution
         is reduced and seen as a privilege. (correct)

     4. Maximum prisons: include different missions such as supermax and individuals stay in their
         (usually single-occupancy) cells for the entire day, every day.

     5. Administrative prisons: Has mostly single-occupancy cells, and many but not all individuals
         housed here will spend most of their day in a cell. Freedom of movement is reduced and seen as a
         privilege.

     6. Answer feedback: All people who go to prisons in the United States are people who have been
         convicted of felony-level crimes and are serving more than a year for their conviction. Prison
         level is associated with the seriousness of crimes committed by the individuals housed within
         these institutions.

Chapter 9: Community Corrections

1. Which type of community corrections is correctly matched to its definition?

     1. Diversion: a process where an individual, at some stage, is routed away from continuing on in
         the formal justice process. (correct)

     2. Probation: where an individual is remanded to stay home for confinement as a punishment, in
         lieu of jail or prison.

     3. Boot camps: Programs that are designed around a militaristic ideal and operated on the assump-
         tion that a regimen of strict physical exercise would teach structure and discipline to youths.
         (correct)

     4. House arrest: a form of a suspended sentence where the jail or prison sentence of the convicted
         individual is suspended for the privilege of serving conditions of supervision in the community.

     5. Halfway houses: a stopping point for individuals coming out of prisons to assist with reentry
         into the community. They have also recently been used as more secure measures of monitoring
         individuals in place of going to prison. (correct)

     6. Parole: an individual's release (under conditions) after serving a portion of their sentence. It is
         also accompanied by the threat of re-incarceration if warranted. (correct)

     7. Answer feedback: Like incarcerated corrections, community corrections have similar goals: to

                                                                                                                                        331
         promote public safety, administer punishment, and rehabilitate individuals, but unlike incarcer-
         ated corrections, this is done in a very different way.
2. Probation is celebrated as being a form of community corrections that is over 95% successful.

     1. True
     2. False (correct)
     3. Answer feedback: There are mixed reviews about probation. Recently, the Bureau of Justice Sta-

         tistics listed the successful completion rate at about 43 percent in 2020. In 2008-2013, this num-
         ber has been reported higher, upwards of 65 percent.
3. Which of the following are true about reentry and recidivism in the United States?

     1. Most people who are released from incarceration will be rearrested (correct)
     2. The United States has the lowest reentry rate in the world.
     3. Many of the deficits that lead to people's incarceration (lack of education and training, legal ser-

         vices, public benefits) are the same predictors that lead to recidivism. (correct)
     4. Criminal records have an adverse impact on apartment rental applications, making it more diffi-

         cult for people to find housing. (correct)
     5. Answer feedback: Without services and social reform around housing and employment, people

         who have previously been incarcerated will have a difficult time reintegrating into society. Many
         return to prison, hence the concept of the "revolving door" of justice.
4. Over the last 100 years, the number of people incarcerated in the U.S. has gone down.

     1. True
     2. False (correct)
     3. Answer feedback: In 1925, there were under 200,000 people in prison in the U.S. As of 2019, the

         U.S. prison population had grown to about 1.4 million people.
5. Which of the following are true about specialty courts?

     1. Drug Courts are a type of specialty court. (correct)
     2. In terms of cost savings compared to jail or prison, they are seen as an effective community alter-

         native. (correct)
     3. Specialty courts are no longer in use, as they are shown to cause more harm than good.
     4. Individuals who have been through drug courts have shown lower rates of being rearrested for a

         drug crime than their comparison group. (correct)
     5. Answer feedback: Specialty Courts handle individuals charged or convicted with specific crimes

         or who have specific needs. Overall, they are a cost-effective alternative to jails and prisons. Drug
         courts show lower rates of rearrest than their comparison group.

Chapter 10: Juvenile Justice

1. During the end of the 19th century, what movement emerged to change the way the state was deal-
    ing with dependent, neglected, and delinquent children? This movement primarily consisted of
    women from middle and upper-class backgrounds.

     1. Child-savers (correct)
     2. Parens patriae

332
    3. Juvenile justice
    4. Law enforcement
    5. Answer feedback: The influx of people into cities weakened community cohesion and care for

         children (Feld, 1999). The child-saving movement changed state management of dependent,
         neglected, and delinquent children. It drew women from middle and upper-class backgrounds.
2. Which of the following are areas of the juvenile court due process that changed drastically beginning
    in the 1960s? Select all that apply.
    1. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act. (correct)
    2. Juvenile justice reform that is driven by evidence-based practices. (correct)
    3. In the 1980s-1990s, there was a growing emphasis on punishment. (correct)
    4. A nationwide uniform juvenile justice system.
    5. Answer feedback: There is no uniform juvenile justice system in the United States. Consequences
         for minors and children who break the law are subject to the discretion of individual states and
         their legislative bodies. States legislate according to their own priorities.
3. In most juvenile cases, the courts seek an informal process or the least restrictive option.
    1. True (correct)
    2. False
    3. Answer feedback: In most juvenile cases, the least restrictive option is usually sought, so the
         youth is usually put on probation or community treatment. Formal processing is less common
         than informal processing involving diversion or community-based programming.
4. A waiver allows a judge to transfer a juvenile to adult court.
    1. True (correct)
    2. False
    3. Answer feedback: All states have enacted laws that allow juveniles to be tried in adult criminal
         courts. There are several ways a juvenile can be transferred to adult criminal court including a
         prosecutorial, legislative, or judicial waiver.
5. All states have transfer laws that allow or require young offenders to be prosecuted as adults for
    more serious offenses, regardless of age.
    1. True (correct)
    2. False
    3. Answer feedback: In 45 states, the maximum age of juvenile court jurisdiction is age 17. Five
         states - Georgia, Michigan, Missouri, Texas, and Wisconsin - draw the line at age 16. Every state
         allows young offenders to be prosecuted as adults for more serious offenses.

This image illustrates Classical Conditioning as developed by Ivan Pavlov. First a dog salivates when it
sees meat. This is an unconditioned response. Next a dog has no response when it hears a bell. The bell is
a neural stimulus. Next, a dog salivates when it hears the bell when seeing the meat. This is also an uncon-
ditioned response to a neural stimulus. Finally a dog salivates when it hears the bell. This is the desired
conditioned response to a conditioned stimulus.

Description for Figure 5.8, The Diagram of the Stakes of Conformity outlines four
factors that influence human behavior. Imagine someone experiences low
attachment, low commitment, low belief, and low involvement. Would this lead
toward conforming behavior or criminal behavior?

This infographic outlines four factors that influence criminal behavior or conforming behavior. The fac-
tors include:

· Attachment
· Commitment
· Belief
· Involvement

Attachment includes friends, chosen or biological family, and/or community. The absence of attachment
can increase criminal behavior. The presence of attachment increases conforming behavior.

   Commitment includes future, personal growth, career success, and/or personal goals. The absence of
commitment can increase criminal behavior. The presence of commitment increases conforming behav-
ior.

   Belief includes honesty, morality, equity, civic duty, and/or responsibility. The absence of belief can
increase criminal behavior. The presence of belief increases conforming behavior.

   Involvement includes school activities, sports teams, community organizations, religious groups, and/
or social clubs. The absence of involvement can lead to criminal behavior. The presence of involvement
conforming behavior.

numbers of prisoners continue to remain so high?

Peggy's Story
   [Peggy, mother to victim of arson-related homicide]: I deliver mail and I was out on my route delivering

mail and here the supervisors - two of them whipped up in front of me. My dad's in bad, was in bad
shape, he's on oxygen, and I thought something happened to my dad. And so they come running over to
my car and I said, "Is it my dad?" and they said, they shook their head no, and I said, "Is it one of my kids?"
and they went like that [nods] and I said, "Is it my son?"

   My son was a senior at the University of Pittsburgh and a girl that lived on the second floor, her ex-
boyfriend set a fire and the smoke, you know, killed my son while he was upstairs sleeping.

   This boy more or less was - I don't know if he was stalking her or what, you
   know, jealous or whatever - and you know, set the fire and intended to kill her and, you know, Joey
didn't make it, you know.
   We buried him on Monday and I think it was Thursday, was when the detective called me to tell me
that it had been an arson. And he wanted to let the family know before it hit the news while I was by
myself when he told me and yeah I just couldn't imagine. The trials would start and stuff and the first
time I took my daughter was when the trial was actually going to start and ever since that day that she's
seen this Matthew I've had to sleep with her and that was back in July.
   Chrissy and I was watching TV one day and they said how one act, stupid act, can affect so many lives
and she looked at me and she said, "We really know that mom, don't we," but you
   figure this boy was jealous or whatever about this girl living with this guy or I don't understand what
he was thinking of, but his stupid act has ruined lives of people he didn't even know. We've never done
anything to him. I've never got a traffic ticket, nothing, and to be punished like this, we'll be punished the
rest of our lives because of someone we didn't even know.
   If he would have been in an accident with - where he was drinking or if he would have been in a
car accident, where was an accident or something, but to know that someone deliberately, while he was
sleeping that.... Where is the safest place you think your child is? In bed sleeping.
   He's the - what this kid did is - he has no idea how he has affected all of us. I mean just the emptiness,
the sick feeling that you have inside you every single day. Not a day goes by that I don't, do not shed a
tear. Not one day.

   When I told my mom, I remember we were in my room and I just kind of broke down. I started crying

I mean, she was upset, she was hurt, and I didn't tell her who it was. I didn't tell her for about a year or so

   She got me into therapy right away, it was never a question of are you sure this happened, you know,
are you sure you're not making this up or you're just remembering things wrong? She never doubted me
and to this day I wish I had said something to her years before but I couldn't.
   I was depressed for a long time. I didn't even realize I was so depressed for a long time. All I ever did
was sit in my room and watch television and eat.
   I have a hard time trusting people or I just jump in like feet first without them giving me any reason to
really trust them. Usually I find I've gotten burned like a lot of times but it's like, because I did, I feel as
though as when I was that young I wanted to be able to do that with someone and I couldn't, so now I'm
still kind of looking for that.
   When I walk into a room, within ten minutes of being in that room, I know every way out of that room,
including if I had to jump out a window, and it's just, it's like instinct to me now. I don't even realize that
I do it anymore but just, I'm always looking for an out. I'm never trying to be trapped in the corner, never
again.
   I recognize now that it's not about sex at all, it's all about power. I really do fear that a lot of them get
off on that, um, the whole idea of you hurt me, you know, you're hurting people. I think that's what, that's
what they're looking for.
   It's weird for me to talk about this cause it's so third-person, cause I do feel as though she's still with

okay to cry. I'm still angry. I think I have every right to be angry but it doesn't, it doesn't ruin my life any-

   Ron's Story
   [Ron, victim of child abuse and neglect]: It was a part of my childhood to be beaten so badly that my
eyes would be swollen shut for days on end. I had an uncle who was, um, he was a sadist. He was, um,
brutal. He was, um, he was absolutely insane and I suffered beatings at his hands time and time and time
again. He would be the only father figure that I would know as a child because my mother and him lived

son. Any, any small thing that annoyed her, it was taken out on us kids.
   My mother handed me over to a pedophile when I was five and by then, I, you would have thought that
I was conditioned to handle, um, the horrors of my life but this added a new dimension to my suffering
and I found it almost unbearable to deal with. So as a kindergartner I would have to leave kindergarten
class and go home and have sex with this man who was in his 50s. I remember the long walk home and
crying and falling down and having to get back
   up and walking on and falling down and crying and getting back up and walking on. I had to adjust to
that situation. I had no choice but to shoulder this responsibility and I learned that food and sex for me.
   Young in life, I turned to drugs and that would be a friend of mine for a long, long time. My journey
has been an enormous struggle for me. I've known years and years of depression. I've, I've been physically
sick in times in my life. I lost my job, I had no friends. I assumed I would die. I never expected to live
through, live through this.
   I don't think being abused as a child goes away. There's things that I do deal with as an adult now that
it's kind of like problem troubleshooting. I maintain taking care of my mental health
   and my emotional health and I've learned over the years to be fairly good at it. I know that I am a high-
functioning abuse survivor. I have a propensity towards honesty whereas my siblings don't, they, they
want to just forget it, they don't want to think about it, but I think it's more insidious than that. We were
made to witness crimes committed against one another over and over again, it's like where we hold the
truth and we can't get near one another. It's too horrible to even see each other. It's so painful.
   Kimberly's Story
   [Kimberly, victim of a crime against a person with a disability]: When I was 16 years old, a senior in
high school, my girlfriend and I were coming home from snow skiing and she had just taken her eyes off
the road for a minute and we hit a truck. And my neck was crushed and it left me paralyzed from the
neck down.
   After I had recovered from my injury and kind of built back some self esteem and confidence, I was
a senior in college and had a boyfriend. Shortly after we became engaged I heard him refer to me as his
pretty bird in a cage and I think it just sent chills down my spine. When I heard that I always had to come
home from class on time and tell him where I was going and when I would be back and when I came in
from class, I was a few minutes late, and when I came in the door he was sitting on the couch and he had
a butcher knife in his hand. He grabbed me by my feet and pulled me out of the wheelchair. He climbed
on top of me and held my arms down with his knees and he started choking me and stabbing the butcher
knife around my head.
   At that point in time I realized my life was in danger and I didn't want to stay in this relationship but
it was just three weeks later, um, that he had pretty much held me hostage throughout the night and I
was admitted into the hospital with a broken arm, broken nose, broken ribs, and my sternum was per-

344
manently damaged. Then at that point it took. The hospital, the police, the University and my family all
stepped in and got me out of that relationship and it was about a year later when the trial was starting for
the first charge and I went into that courtroom with the utmost confidence that the person that did this
to me would be punished for what he did.

   It was a five day trial. On the witness stand his attorney portrayed me as a woman with a severe dis-
ability that no other man would ever want or ever loved and how wonderful his client was for giving up
his life to take care of me, and in a jury of 12, my batterer was found not guilty. That was completely dev-
astating for me. I felt revictimized only this time by the system, but what was so difficult for me is I knew
there were other people that went through experiences of domestic violence but I felt like I was alone as
a person with a disability going through that. And there were so many layers of issues with my disability
that contributed to the abuse and made it more difficult to get away and to recover from.

   I had moved to California after the abusive relationship and I was out there and I had just completed
my master's degree in social work and this was six years later in `96 and it was one Friday evening about
eight o'clock. I was sitting on the living room floor and I had my bedroom window open, not unlike all
the other apartments in my complex, and I heard a noise in my bedroom. I called for my caregiver to
come to see what the noise was and the next thing I saw was she was walking out of my bedroom back-
wards and there was a man that had a gun to her head and behind him was another man with a knife.
Then the man with the gun went to the sliding glass door opened the door, in, in walked two more men
so there were now four men in my apartment and they pulled all of the phone cords and all of the lights
out and they burglarized my home and I was raped and repeatedly told that they were going to kill me.

   I know that the reason I was chosen is because of my vulnerabilities with my disability. I could not run
from them, I could not fight back, I hardly even have the strength in my voice to be able

   to yell. I'm an easy victim, an easy target. Those four men were never caught.
   I see all of the additional stigma in our society for people with disabilities. I see how they are being tar-
geted for crime and abuse and for me I felt like those experiences happened to me and I don't want to just
bury them and not do anything with those experiences. And people with disabilities is a huge population
and I think it's important for everyone to realize that people with disabilities want to be treated fairly and
equally in our society like everyone else and we want to have the same services and the same respect as
everyone else in our society.

   If you've committed a crime and it is totally shut out and you going on with your life, that family,

   Jee Young's Story
   [ Jee Young, sister to victim of a hate crime]: My name is Jee Young and I'm the sister of [name inaudi-

ries, still something I avoid doing.
   It was a Sunday and I think he was playing basketball with our church youth group, Korean church

would keep on pushing, snicker about it together, you know.

                                                                                                                                        347
   So it came up to a point where it grew into an argument and my brother said I had enough, we're going

   After they spit on his face, they knocked him to the ground, four or five, maybe more kids started to
step, stomp and kick his head, face and back. He was lying on the ground, he did not fight back. All the

nerve damage so he lost sensation on this four of his upper tooth and whole bottom, um, all that part
doesn't have sensation until now and it's been about a year since that happened.

   The police report was that they wrote it up as if it was a gang fight that, um, they were playing basket-

white gang and that offends me just because of the description of how I look and how we are.

   The image of my brother falling on that concrete floor and people stepping and just kicking with shoes
on his face, I can't get that image out of my head. What goes through one's mind when they kick and step
on a living human being just covering his face and head to survive? What does one have to do to deserve
all this, getting into an argument playing basketball?

   I had a chance to read my victim impact statement at the court. I wanted to see the kids who did this
to my brother and I, after I read my statement I said, um, just because someone speaks less English than
you, just because someone looks a little different than you and whether if it's the same, that doesn't give
you any right to step, to kick or spit on someone's face and the response I got from him was. I'm sorry I
caused you such inconvenience but if you think I'm a racist, I'm not, because I don't treat people by their
color.

   Hate crime, you know, it's not something explicit that you can see. You are just hitting or you are just
punching someone in your anger, your frustration but then pack the hurt that that person has they carry
on for life and the people around that person who love him or her they carry on the same pain. To see
someone that you really love suffer and go through pain that's not an easy thing to carry because it always
stays in the back of your mind and it really hurts.

   Amy's Story
   [Amy, family member of a victim of homicide]: Jill was on the second floor. The first floor apartment

   She had been there too much, she had no idea he was waiting for her when she returned
